userInput.prompt: i want to pass the JLPT N2

testCase.expectations:
- should include "JLPT" without the "N2" level suffix
      - should include "Japanese"
      - all titles and descriptions in US English
      - no extra titles like "Japanese Language Proficiency Test", "JLPT N2 Preparation", etc
      - should NOT include any other suggestions

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None. The response follows the language exam edge-case rule with exactly two suggestions, uses US English, includes the exact titles "JLPT" and "Japanese" without levels or extra variants, keeps titles in Title Case, and provides one-sentence descriptions.

Very minor stylistic issues: the JLPT description is generic ("all aspects") and the second description uses slightly awkward phrasing ("academic, work, or personal growth" could be "academic, professional, or personal growth").

Tighten descriptions to better convey value without adding level details, e.g., for JLPT: highlight test strategies, vocabulary, and grammar coverage; for Japanese: emphasize communication fluency for study, career, and daily life. Replace "work" with "professional" for smoother US English style.

testCase.expectations:

      - all titles and descriptions in US English

steps.conclusion: The output fails to include the exact IP title “The Matrix” as a standalone suggestion, instead using “Matrix Movie,” which violates the instruction to include the exact topic name when the input targets a specific IP and contradicts the expectation to include “The Matrix.”

Minor naming and style issues: the description says “the Matrix movie” instead of the proper “The Matrix,” and “Matrix Movie” does not read like a natural course title; otherwise titles are in Title Case, one-sentence descriptions are met, and language is US English.

Rename the first title to “The Matrix”; optionally add more relevant suggestions (e.g., “Cyberpunk,” “Artificial Intelligence,” “Simulation Theory,” “Visual Effects,” “Action Choreography,” “Philosophy of Mind”) and consider making “Science Fiction” more film-focused (“Science Fiction Film”) to align with the movie theme.
